feed.title: SAP Community - SAP Extended Warehouse Management
feed.subtitle: SAP Extended Warehouse Management blog posts in SAP Community

entry.title: Which Synchronous Posting is enabled from EWM to S4 & relevant Service Class for posting.
entry.content:
Synopsis: Understanding which of the business processes are activated as 'Synchronous Posting' from EWM to S4. There is lot of stuff available in SAP community related to synchronous posting from S4 to EWM( Inbound External Receipts and Inbound Internal Receipt( MO), primarily a MIGO capability However, there are even direct synchronous posting conducted from EWM2S4. 

Requirement: Synchronous posting from EWM2S4 are generally required because of following reasons. 

  • Avoid hanging queue from EWM2S4 
  • Avoid stock inconsistencies between EWM & S4
  • Real time storage location extension during posting from /SCWM/ADGI( GM code=04, NWLO from EWM to non-EWM storage location).    

Logic of Synchronous Posting from EWM2S4: Activation at warehouse level( SPRO-->Extended Warehouse Management-->Interfaces-->Goods Movements-->Activate Synchronous Goods Movement Posting)

/SCWM/CL_ERP_GOODSMVT_SYNC_S4 is the maintain service class for synchronous posting from EWM2S4.

Two important methods play a pivotal role for synchronous posting

/SCWM/IF_ERP_GOODSMVT_SYNC~SIMULATE_POSTING--> This method checks the corresponding S4 Data like sufficient stock availability or even master data extension like 'material is extended to storage location or nor in real time to avoid hanging queues and display of error at 'UI Level' at 10 EWM relevant transaction.

IS_GM_CODE_ALLOWED: This is the main method displaying the EWM relevant transaction meant for Synchronous posting from EWM to S4. There are total relevant processes, the blog will highlight the /SCWM/ADGI synchronous capability only from EWM to S4.

 

  Below example is moving a Material from EWM managed to IM managed storage location using /SCWM/ADGI, GM Code=4)

System does the real time storage location extension check instead of posting and creating a hanging queue( If No Auto Sloc creation is enable in 411 Mvt type in S4). 

The class /SCWM/CL_ERP_GOODSMVT_SYNC_S4 with method /SCWM/IF_ERP_GOODSMVT_SYNC~SIMULATE_POSTING performs all relevant synchronous posting simulation before posting goods movement. In below example, a real time stock availability check is performed during a Material movement from EWM to IM managed storage location.

Similarly all relevant synchronous posting can be conducted from EWM2S4 with below transaction as well which are mentioned 

  • Difference analyzer(/SCWM/DIFF_ANALYZER)
  • Difference analyzer(/DIFF_ANA_CAT_CHG)- Stock category change during posting.
  •  Initial Stock upload( /SCWM/ISU)
  • Posting change ( /SCWM/POST ) 
  • /Unplanned Goods Issue( /SCWM/RGI_SCRAP)- /SCWM/ADGI
  • Stock type change report( R_STOCK_TYPE_CHANGE )
  • monitor posting change via 'BBD/SLED Overview'--->MON_DDATES_PC', 
  • monitor posting change via 'Physical Stock--> 'MON_PHYSTO_PC',
  • Consumption against PMR- 'MFG_GI', 
  • Goods Movement Kanban Staging task Wbse to PSA- TO_KANBAN', 

Thanks for reading. All relevant information replicated is based on my personal experience and insight. Relevant tests have been performed in S/4 HANA 2023 FPS02 system.

entry.title: EWM – STO using same HU number
entry.content:
INTRODUCTION
This guide will demonstrate how to configure the system to retain the same handling unit (HU) number during an STO process between two EWM storage locations. It does not cover the settings for the STO process itself.

PROCESS OVERVIEW
Let's consider a scenario with two warehouses where they use the same handling unit types in both warehouses and we want to maintain the same handling unit number during a transfer between plants using STO process. To achieve that we must maintain the same interval number for HU in both warehouses as we can see in the example below:

Note: The same interval number should be designated as internal in only one warehouse to prevent overlaps and issues. In all other warehouses, the same interval number must be set as external.

PROCESS FLOW

  • Create transfer PO in the receiving plant.
  • Create outbound delivery in VL10B for supplying plant.
  • Create WT, pick HU's, confirm with RF and execute PGI in supplying plant.
  • Inbound delivery is created through output type SPED with same HU numbers in the receiving plant.
  • Create WT and complete WH putaway process in receiving plant.

CUSTOMIZING
In this topic will be described the customizing to set up correctly the interval numbers to achieve the requirement. The settings regarding the STO process and the SPED output type could be found in the respective blogs below:

  • STO Process
    https://community.sap.com/t5/supply-chain-management-blog-posts-by-members/intracompany-sto-with-in-the-plant-between-two-ewm-managed-warehouses/ba-p/13589053

  • Output Type SPED
    https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/output-type-sped-trigger-inbound-delivery-after-pgi-for-inter-company-sto-s/ba-p/13505818

 

  • SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Cross-Process Settings -> Handling Units -> External Identification -> Define Number Range for HU Identification

    In the warehouse 1000 the range 00000000030000000000 00000000039999999999 is maintained as internal as we can see below:


    On the other hand, at warehouse 1030 the same interval number is maintained as external as we can see:
    Note: besides the interval, the "Number Range No." which has the value 01 must be the same! Otherwise, you will get errors in SMQ2 when the inbound delivery is distributed to the EWM.

  • SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Cross-Process Settings -> Handling Units -> External Identification -> Assign Number Range Intervals to Packaging Material Types

    In this customizing, ensure that the packing material types use the internal number range for their respective warehouses, as shown in the example below. When a handling unit is created in the warehouse, a new number will be assigned automatically.


  • SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Goods Receipt Process -> Strategies -> Storage Bin Determination -> HU Types -> Define HU Types for Each Warehouse Number and Assign HU Type Group

    In this customizing, ensure that the HU type is assigned to both warehouses.

  • SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Goods Receipt Process -> Strategies -> Storage Bin Determination -> HU Types -> Define HU Types for Each Storage Type

    In this customization, ensure that the HU type is assigned to the storage types where the handling units will be stored.

  • SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Goods Receipt Process -> Strategies -> Storage Bin Determination -> HU Types -> Define HU Types for Each Storage Bin Type

    In this customizing, ensure that the HU type is assigned to the appropriate storage bin types where the handling units will be stored.

TESTING
Stock transport order created from 1000 (supplying plant) to 1030 (receiving plant):


Outbound delivery order for the supplying plant created through VL10B:


Outbound process in EWM complete (Picking WT completed + PGI):

Handling Units picked in EWM were transferred to outbound delivery:

Note: for this example, we are using nested HU's.

Checking the SPED output type responsible for creating the inbound delivery at the receiving plant using the same HU numbers:

Now checking the flow document on the outbound delivery we can see the inbound delivery created:

In the inbound delivery at the receiving plant, the same nested HU was created using the same numbers from the supplying plant as follows:

Complete the WH putaway process in the receiving plant:

By checking the stock for the transferred handling units, we can see the stock in the receiving plant at warehouse 1030, using the same HU numbers as in the supplying plant:

CONCLUSION
The approach outlined in this blog demonstrates that it is possible to retain the same handling unit number during stock transfers between plants when using the STO process with output type SPED. This strategy enhances traceability and eliminates the need for re-labeling stock upon arrival at the receiving plant. 

I try to make it simple, hope this guide helps you guys.

Best Regards,

Yuri Taranto
SAP EWM Consultant

entry.title: Enhancing warehouse operations by integrating robotics with SAP Extended Warehouse Management
entry.content:
Introduction

Warehouse automation has been steadily gaining momentum, with robotic automation taking center stage in recent years. It is estimated that robot shipments to increase by up to 50 percent each year through 2030, with warehouse automation growing by more than 10 percent a year. The evolution from custom-built robots to modular and scalable platforms has marked a significant shift in the industry. This transformation is the result of advances in cloud technology, affordability of hardware for data storage and processing, significant improvements in sensor and computer vision technology, and more recently AI. Additionally, the availability of integration mechanisms and standards has enabled warehouse of all sizes to adopt robotic automation. While there is a wide choice of robot vendors, a robust and scalable warehouse management system is needed at the heart of the warehouse automation strategy.

In this blog series we explore how SAP S/4HANA Extended Warehouse Management (SAP EWM) enables robotic automation via seamless orchestration and task assignments while providing real-time visibility into the robotic automated processes.

Business and Operations Drivers for Robotic Automation

Warehousing plays a critical role in the logistics orchestration of any supply chain when it comes to order fulfillment. Companies must juggle multiple factors to maintain timely deliveries to their customers such as

  • Keeping pace with order volumes while meeting customer service expectations of shorter lead times and order accuracy
  • Handling increasing number of stock-keeping-units (SKUs)
  • Addressing labor shortages while looking for ways to increase workforce productivity and worker safety
  • Managing operating costs associated with handling and storage
  • Ensuring accurate inventory
  • Maximizing space utilization

Specific industry needs layer additional factors:

  • Since COVID, e-commerce and retail industries went through a massive transformation. Companies around the globe have had to deal with massive increases in order volumes needing fast omnichannel fulfillment that require accurate picking in their warehouses and distribution centers, which in some countries has led to the evolution of quick commerce.
  • The manufacturing industry has the need to precisely handle materials and components and synchronize warehouse operations with production, for example managing Just-in-Time supply to the production lines, and intralogistics operations.
  • The third-party logistics companies who serve multiple clients need the ability to run their warehouses efficiently with a high degree of accuracy to be able to handle large volumes of products that flow through their facilities.

Lastly, disruptions caused by ongoing geopolitical tensions, extreme weather events, port congestions, maritime route disturbances, and trade wars continue to pressure companies to build greater resilience. As a result, to strengthen their end-to-end logistics process, companies are increasingly adopting robotics in their warehouse operations as an added dimension of automation to boost speed, throughput, and accuracy. Robots like high density storage and retrieval systems (ASRS), goods-to-person robots, collaborative robots (cobots) that work safely alongside humans, shuttle systems and AMRs perform functions that span a wide range of scenarios, providing several benefits to warehouse operations such as:

  • Increased Efficiency: Robots can handle repetitive tasks such as picking, packing, and sorting faster and more accurately than humans. This leads to quicker fulfillment of orders and improved throughput.
  • Reduced Labor Costs: By automating manual tasks, warehouses can reduce their dependence on human labor, which can lower costs like hiring and training.
  • Enhanced Accuracy: Robots equipped with advanced sensors and algorithms can minimize errors in tasks such as inventory management, ensuring higher accuracy in order fulfillment and reducing the return rate.
  • Consistent Performance: Robots can work continuous shifts without fatigue, maintaining consistent performance over time and increasing the reliability of operations.
  • Safety Improvement: Automating heavy lifting and other potentially dangerous tasks can reduce the risk of workplace injuries and accidents, ensuring a safer environment for human workers.
  • Scalability and Flexibility: Robotics systems can be scaled up or down depending on demand. They can also be reprogrammed for different tasks, providing flexibility in operations and facilitating adaptation to changing business needs.
  • Optimized Space Utilization: Robots can navigate tight spaces and difficult layouts, making it possible to optimize warehouse layout and storage, thereby maximizing the use of available space.
  • 24/7 Operation: Unlike human workers, robots can operate around the clock without breaks, enabling continuous operations and faster processing times.
  • Data Collection and Analysis: Warehouse robots can gather valuable data on operations, which can be analyzed to improve efficiencies, forecast inventory needs, and optimize warehouse management strategies.
  • Reduction in Human Error: Automation reduces the likelihood of human errors in processes such as inventory counts and order placement, enhancing overall accuracy.

Robotic Automation with SAP EWM

Before implementing robotic automation, companies should carefully evaluate their specific use cases to ensure that the technology aligns with their business needs and objectives. The use cases typically fall into the following areas:

  • loading / unloading,
  • put-away,
  • robotic / collaborative picking,
  • sorting,
  • packing,
  • palletizing / depalletizing,
  • replenishing.

And there is a high likelihood that as the use of robots proliferates in the warehouses, there will be a heterogeneous landscape of robot vendors making integration into the warehouse management systems very complex. To orchestrate seamless warehouse operations, a robust warehouse management system is central to the system landscape. It should be agnostic to various robotic types and vendors, providing the necessary APIs and business objects to enable efficient integration.

With customers in 24 industries across 75 industries, SAP EWM has been serving the warehouse management needs for decades. SAP EWM provides comprehensive automation capabilities for various warehouse processes.  SAP’s approach to robotic automation with SAP EWM is built upon these core capabilities and providing customers a choice of specialized partners with certified integration to SAP EWM as illustrated below.

Source: SAP EWM Product Management (Note: the partners listed are not an exhausted list)

These partners fall into two categories and work in concert with SAP EWM:

  • OEM Fleet Management System that integrates and manages robots from different manufacturers within a single system
  • Multiagent Orchestration Platform, a term coined by Gartner. These platforms act like intelligent middleware that integrates and orchestrates work between various business applications, heterogeneous fleets of operational robots, and other automated agents like doors or elevators. These solutions orchestrate and assign work and monitor and coordinate the activities of diverse fleets of robots.

Partner solutions for both categories can be found on SAP Store:

Partner

Solution

Description

Locus Robotics, Inc.

Locus Autonomous Mobile Robots for SAP EWM

Innovative autonomous mobile robots integrate with SAP Extended Warehouse Management to work collaboratively alongside workers in fast-paced logistics and fulfillment industries. Workers can pick 2-3 times faster with near 100% accuracy and less labor, delivering higher productivity.

Geekplus Technology Co., Ltd.

Improve efficiency of your warehouse operation by 2 to 3 times

P series AMR picking robots to move the inventory shelves and pallets to the picking station, completely eliminating the redundant walking of picking workers, improving picking accuracy, and reducing labor intensity. It integrates with SAP EWM and handle orders from it. A partner that is a member of SAP’s curated startup ecosystem.

DXC Technology Services LLC

DXC Smart Warehouse EWM Integration with AGVs

The solution, built on SAP BTP, seamlessly integrates SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) with advanced automation technologies such as robotic picking systems, Automated Guided Vehicles (AGVs), and sophisticated conveyor belts. This integration greatly enhances operational efficiency in warehouses by streamlining processes, accelerating dispatch times, reducing the likelihood of human errors, and cutting labor costs.

Flexus AG

AGV-Hub - Fleet Manager for Mobile Robots

One fleet manager to control your whole fleet of mobile robots: traffic management, battery management, evacuations, idle management, and an overview of all errors. Monitor all vehicles with or without the VDA5050 and connect them seamlessly into your SAP systems like SAP EWM, SAP Production Planning or SAP Stock Room Management.

KINEXON Industries GmbH

Connect and automate operations: redefine manufacturing & logistics efficiency

Elevate productivity and sustainability: Track and trace all moving assets in real-time and orchestrate all mobile robots (AMR/AGV) in production and intralogistics. Enhance production speed, quality, scalability, and efficiency. Build a digital twin and automate at scale. Seamlessly integrate with SAP Digital Manufacturing and SAP Extended Warehouse Management for operational synergy and E2E process management.

Roboteon Inc.

Roboteon Fulfillment Platform

Plug into and optimize existing automated warehouse distribution operations running on SAP EWM. Plan, simulate and deploy greenfield automation projects. Design automation strategies in a mixed SAP landscape: part or fully automated, or fully manual operations looking to automate. Leverage IDOC or API based integration on SAP BTP. We also support older SAP EWM releases moving to SAP Extended Warehouse Management, industry add-on for SAP S/4HANA.

To efficiently integrate warehouse robotics and fleet management systems to EWM on SAP S/4HANA, we are continuously working to enhance availability, capability and extensibility and providing the necessary APIs. You can find these APIs for EWM via the SAP Business Accelerator Hub by entering “warehouse” in the search bar.

Benefits of Warehouse Robotic Automation with SAP EWM

SAP’s approach provides several benefits to customers as they begin to adopt and / or expand the use of robots in their warehouses and fulfillment centers, all in a flexible manner. Standard connectivity and certified integration, including keeping pace with evolving industry standards, helps companies develop their automation strategies in all types of environments – fully manual, partially automated, as well as fully-automated. Working with a choice of partners, both the multi-agent orchestration platforms as well as OEM fleet management system providers, customers can plug into an existing or a greenfield automation environment running on SAP EWM and plan, optimize, simulate and deploy robots to enable collaborative and efficient warehouse task orchestration. The biggest benefit is that customers are not locked into a particular robot vendor, there is no proprietary dependence on any robotics solution. This approach provides the ability to integrate with multiple robot vendors and instances across their facilities allowing customers to choose the best robot solution for the process they are looking to automate.

 Conclusion

The future of warehouse automation depends on seamless integration between SAP EWM and robotics and fleet management systems, where businesses that leverage this integration will gain a competitive edge in efficiency, accuracy, and scalability. In the future blogs in this series, we will explore some of the options SAP provides through our partner ecosystem that integrate with SAP EWM and help unlock the full potential of warehouse robotics.

entry.title: How to display RF Message in a separate Screen - RF Screens with Touch Enablement
entry.content:
In EWM standard RF transactions, the following standard function codes are only available as function key but not as pushbutton prior to S4 HANA 2020

  • Clear input field value ('CLEAR') - F6
  • Return to previous step ('BACK') - F7
  • Display value list of actual field ('LIST') - F8
  • Display message on separate screen ('FULLMS') - F9

Example: If an error message is triggered during execution of a particular RF transaction( I.e Receiving HU by HU MO), the message is partially displayed in current session and to display full message, it is required to press 'F9' to display the full message and then press 'F7' to return to the previous Screen.

On devices without hardware function keys, these function codes either must be triggered via a software keypad or by entering the corresponding value in the shortcut field on the RF device. Both possibilities are not user-friendly and decrease the performance of the RF use

Solution: From S4 HANA 2020 onwards, SAP has released a note '2957972 - RF Framework: Add Standard Function Codes as Pushbuttons which provides to add F6, F7, F8 and F9 as an easy Push button in RF framework and easy navigation of message in a separate screen w/o usage of pressing these in RF Device.

In /SCWM/PRDVC, presentation profile, SAP has given 4 different attribute to show 'Functions as Push Button to be used based on User UI acceptability.

The RF Cookbook has described the attributes of presentation profile pushbutton attributes as below.

 Don’t Add as Buttons This standard function codes are only available by function key.
A Add at End of Button Groups The standard function codes appear after all other function codes assigned in the RF customizing
B Add at Start of Bottom Group The standard function codes appear before all other function codes assigned in the RF customizing
C Sort Buttons According to Function keyThe standard function codes appear according to their function key (between F4 to F10)
D Add Back and Clear in First Button GroupStandard function codes BACK and CLEAR are at the beginning and the remaining standard function code are added at the next button Group
E Add with Customer Implementation Business Add-In (BAdI) Addition of Standard Function Codes as Buttons
(/SCWM/EX_RF_ADD_FC_AS_PB) is called.

To use this functionality, customer have to adjust their 'Display Profile' in customizing. To display the function( F6 to F9) as push button along with 'Message display on a Pop-up message Screen' customer has to configure display profile in customizing in RF.

Extended Warehouse Management-->Mobile Data Entry-->Radio Frequency (RF) Framework-->RF Screen Manager. ( Avoid changing in standard **( 8*40) used for mounted screen on forklift  & *2 Portrait Mode( 15*26) generally used for Handheld devices.

Rather copy ** or *2 in your project requirement.

Change here Message display from '1' to '0'. Standard has be default as 1

Ensure to check the Screen manager has correct 'display message'

Good to test once above settings are performed.

Check /SCWM/RFUI in Fiori as well as in ITS( In this example, I am not using MoBgui). The required standard function codes are only available as an easy Push Button:)

Lets test any RF transaction to check 'Display Message' in a separate screen along with Std Functions as push button. 

System has added 4 std pushbuttons along with Screen specific RF pushbuttons. 

Also an easy List view is available to select the required work center( in RF REHU by MO transaction)

Displaying message in separate Screen and easy return to Previous screen.

Below example, error message are directly navigated to a separate screen( without touching F9 button) and one Press enter button navigates to original screen without pressing F7 on Handheld.

There is also a BAdI also /SCWM/EX_RF_ADD_FC_AS_PB  which allows to implement a customer own logic how the standard function codes are added to the pushbutton groups. The BAdI also has an example implementation which shows how function codes GTEXCP (to display valid exception codes), BACK and CLEAR are added to the first pushbutton group.

Thanks for reading. All tests have been performed in S4 HANA 2023 FPS02 Sandbox system.

Refences: 

2957972 - RF Framework: Add Standard Function Codes as Pushbuttons

3234853 - Error Message /SCWM/UI_RF301 while adding Buttons in tcode /SCWM/PRDVC

entry.title: Unplanned Vendor Returns in SAP EWM
entry.content:
During routine inbound operations, it is possible to receive products from a vendor that are damaged or not suitable for use. In cases where these returns were not planned or initiated through a purchase order, the scenario is classified as an unplanned vendor return.

Such exceptions require a structured process to ensure inventory accuracy and proper documentation. SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) provides robust capabilities to handle unplanned returns through configurable warehouse processes, return reasons, and integration with S/4HANA.

This blog outlines the complete process of managing unplanned vendor returns in SAP EWM. It includes essential configuration steps, such as defining warehouse process types and movement types, and presents a detailed test case demonstrating the return flow from receipt through goods issue and system updates.

S/4 Configuration:

  1. Activate BC Sets

T.Code: SCPR20

  • BC SET : /SCWM/DLV_OUTBOUND_RETURN

 

2. Set up Configuration Control Key

 Path: SPRO>IMG> Material Management>Purchasing> Confirmations> Set up Confirmation Control

3. Set up Quantity Difference Profiles

 Path: SPRO>IMG>Material Management> Purchasing>Confirmations>Set up quantity difference Profiles (GR Automotive)

4. Define Internal Confirmation Categories

 Path: SPRO> IMG> Material Management>Purchasing> Confirmations>Define Internal Confirmation Categories

5. Shipping Point Determination

Path: SPRO> IMG> Logistic Execution>Shipping> Basic Shipping Function> Shipping Point and Goods Receipt Point Determination>Assign Shipping point

 

6. Define Shipping data for plants

Path:SPRO>IMG> Material Management> Purchasing> Purchase order > Set up stock transfer order > Define Shipping data for plant

7. Define Delivery Types

Path: SPRO> IMG> Logistic Execution> Shipping> Deliveries> Define Delivery Types

8. Define Item Category determination in Deliveries

Path:SPRO> IMG> Logistic Execution> Shipping> Define Item Category determination in Deliveries

 

EWM configuration:


1. Map Delivery type and item type in S4 and EWM

Path: SPRO>IMG> SCM EWM> EWM> Interfaces>ERP Integrations > Delivery Processing> Map Document types from ERP system to EWM

 

2. Map Item types from ERP system to EWM

Path:  SPRO> IMG> SCM EWM> EWM> Interfaces>ERP Integrations > Delivery Processing> Map Item types from ERP system to EWM

3. Warehouse Process Type for Planned Vendor Returns

  • Define Warehouse Process Type

Path: SPRO> IMG> SCM EWM> EWM>Cross Processing Settings >Warehouse Task > Define Warehouse Process Type

  • Define Control Indicators for Determining Warehouse Process Types
Path: SPRO> IMG> SCM EWM> EWM>Cross Processing Settings >Warehouse Task > Define Control Indicators for Determining Warehouse Process Types

  • Determine Warehouse Process Types
Path: SPRO> IMG> SCM EWM> EWM>Cross Processing Settings >Warehouse Task > Determine Warehouse Process Types

4. Define Separate Storage type for vendor return products

  • Define storage type
Path: SPRO> IMG> SCM EWM> EWM>Master Data >Define Storage Type

Create Bins and Activit Area and Bin sorting in the storage type.

5. Stock Removal Strategies

  • Specify Stock Removal Strategies
Path: SPRO> IMG> SCM EWM> EWM> Good Issue Process > Strategies > Specify Storage type search sequence

  • Define Stock Removal Control Indicator
Path: SPRO> IMG> SCM EWM> EWM> Good Issue Process > Strategies> Define Stock Removal Control Indicator

  • Determine storage type search sequence for stock removal
Path: SPRO> IMG> SCM EWM> EWM> Good Issue Process > Strategies > Determine storage type search sequence for stock removal

Prerequisites:

  1. Create the material master and extend it to the required warehouse storage locations.
  2. Extend Material Master to Product Master and assign PTDI and PACI to the product.
  3. Create a vendor, extend it to the customer role, and assign shipping condition “01” as configured earlier.
  4. Ensure the return quantity is maintained in the storage type created in the previous step.

Testing:

  1. Create Purchase Order -ME21N
  2. Create Inbound delivery & distribute to EWM- VL31N
  3. Maintain Inbound delivery in EWM- /N/SCWM/PRDI

Once the Inbound Delivery is successfully distributed to EWM, proceed with executing the Unloading and Goods Receipt processes in the system.

Ensure that the Goods Receipt (GR) is successfully posted and updated in the S/4HANA system. If the GR is not reflected in S/4, the system will restrict the creation of a Warehouse Task for returns processing.

The Goods Receipt has been successfully performed and, as shown above, it has been correctly updated in the S/4HANA system.

4. Return to Vendors

/N/SCWM/PRDI> Inbound delivery (Menu)> Follow On Functions> Return to Vendor

As soon as the return posted an outbound delivery will be created as shown in the image below.

 5. Maintain Outbound Delivery Order

As this is an unplanned vendor return, the system directly creates an Outbound Delivery Order to initiate the return process. From the Outbound Delivery, a picking task can then be created to proceed with the goods issue.

 6. Create a Picking warehouse task From GR staging

A Warehouse Task has been created to move the product from storage type 9010 (Goods Receipt Staging) to 9020 (Goods Issue Staging), utilizing the Warehouse Process Type '4050' as configured in EWM Configuration: Step 3. Confirm the Warehouse Task to reflect the physical movement of the product by the warehouse associate from the Goods Receipt (GR) area to the Goods Issue (GI) staging area.

7. Goods Issue

Finally, the products that were received were found to be damaged and are therefore being returned to the vendor. Once the Goods Issue is posted, indicating the physical shipment of goods out of the warehouse, this information must be transmitted to the S/4HANA system to ensure accurate stock updates.

The goods movement has been successfully updated in the S/4HANA system, and movement type '122' was triggered to reflect the unplanned vendor return.

This is how the Unplanned Vendor Returns process is executed in SAP EWM. Regardless of the reason for the return, be it damage, overdelivery, or quality issues, providing a return reason is mandatory and helps drive transparency and accountability in the return process. These reasons can be configured in alignment with specific business requirements to support various operational scenarios.

In this blog, we covered the key configuration steps along with a complete test case demonstrating how to process unplanned returns from initiation to goods movement posting. By setting up the process correctly, businesses can handle exceptions efficiently and ensure real-time inventory accuracy across the warehouse and S/4HANA system.

entry.title: EWM-PP integration Directly stage to next PSA (production line) after GR from manufacturing process
entry.content:
For semi-finished products, there may be a requirement to stage them directly to the next production line immediately after goods receipt from the initial manufacturing process.

This blog explains how to implement this requirement.

Hope your EWM-PP integration will be successful😉

Assumptions: 

Please note that this functionality is available only for Embedded EWM, as it relies on synchronous goods movements.　Use Advanced Production Integration, since PMR will be used for consumption.

Deep dive into the scenario : 

First let's review how putaway and staging works in EWM best practice scenario:

In EWM best practices, goods are typically put away into a storage bin after goods receipt from the manufacturing process. Staging to the next Production Supply Area (PSA) occurs after the subsequent production order is released.

However, for semi-finished products, there may be a requirement to stage them directly to the next production line immediately after goods receipt from the initial manufacturing process as described below. 

  • No need to wait for the release of the next production order
  • Goods are directly put away to the next PSA after goods receipt

Configuration steps :

To support the scenario “Stage directly to the next production line after GR”, the following configuration steps are required:

1) Maintain Production Version, 

T-code:  C223

Maintain the other data such as Warehouse number, Receiving location (storage location) ,

・Destination Bin: The PSA bin where you want to directly put away the goods without intermediate staging.

・Target PSA : Next PSA you want to putaway directly after goods receipt from production order.

 2) Maintain Production Scheduling profile 

T-code : OPKP

Synchronous goods movements will be used so please maintain as following

・Post Synchronously to bin："3. Goods receipt and Goods Issue”

3) Set up Synchronous goods movement for warehouse

You can activate synchronous goods movements or deactivate synchronous goods movements in a warehouse for individual goods movement types based on a combination of the movement type and the direction of the goods movement from the warehouse perspective.  In this scenario I have activated synchronous goods movement warehouse level for all transfer movement types, goods receipt movement types or goods issue movement types. 

Path : SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Interfaces -> ERP Integration -> Goods Movements -> Activate Synchronous Goods Movement Posting

・Activate your warehouse number

Let's test goods receipt to next PSA.

1. Create your production order and release.

  T-code: Co01

2. Goods receipt to next PSA .

T-code: MIGO

Enter your production order.

In the warehouse management tab you will be able to see the destination bin you maintained in Production version.

You can also create HU automatically and manually.  To create manually Select "By Total quantity " or " By Quantity per HU" .

Check item and post.

✏️Important Note:

If you're not creating HUs, be sure that you don't set Production supply storage type as "HU required" keep it "HU allowed but not required"  

Path : SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Master Data -> Define Storage Types

3. You will be able to see the received semi-finished products in your next PSA bin.

T-code: /SCWM/MON

Check Next PSA storage bin.

You can find out the GR warehouse task from Warehouse monitor ( /SCWM/MON) or from production order.

Hoping EWM will support many of your production integration scenarios.😍

 

Additional information:

・If you want to create warehouse task to next PSA check below

Automatic Warehouse Task Creation to next Production Supply Area for Semifinished Products | SAP Help Portal

S/4HANA 2022 What’s New – Target PSA in EWM with A... - SAP Community

・If you want to create HU automatically check below

Communication of Goods Movements from Production | SAP Help Portal

Also questions can be asked here.

Thank you!!!!

entry.title: SAP Fiori Physical Inventory Application Process
entry.content:
SAP Fiori:

SAP Fiori is a user experience (UX) design system developed by SAP for creating intuitive, responsive, and easy-to-use applications across devices. It simplifies business processes by offering role-based apps that present only relevant information and actions to the user. Fiori apps are built using SAPUI5, a JavaScript-based framework, and follow consistent design guidelines.
They can run on multiple platforms—desktop, tablet, and mobile—providing a seamless experience.
SAP Fiori enhances productivity and user satisfaction by transforming traditional SAP GUI transactions into modern, consumer-grade interfaces.

Physical Inventory:

Physical inventory in SAP is the process of counting and verifying the actual stock in a warehouse or storage location. It ensures that the system stock matches the physical stock on hand, helping maintain inventory accuracy. SAP supports various inventory types like periodic, continuous, and cycle counting. The process involves creating a physical inventory document, counting stock, entering the results, and posting differences. It is essential for financial accuracy, audit compliance, and efficient warehouse operations.

SAP Fiori Physical Inventory Application Process:

Step1: Open the app “Create Physical Inventory” in SAP Fiori

Enter the details.

Warehouse Number

Product

Provide the physical inventory procedure as HS and Check Active PI document and execute.

Select line item in which bin we are going to be counting and click on create.

Will get a message Doc – 6000 is created

 

Step2: Open the app “Warehouse Monitor”

Provide the below details:

Warehouse Number: MN01

Monitor: SAP

Select physical inventory. Enter document number and execute, will get the details.

 

 

Step3: Open the app “RF Environment” to count.

Counting of Components per PI Doc

Click on the “05 Internal Processes”

Then click on the “01 Inventory counting”

Then click on the “02 Inventory counting manually”

Enter the warehouse order number and then click on enter.

Scan the details

Enter Storage Bin and click on enter

Scan the Product and quantity. Then click on next

Scan the quantity. Then click on next.

Then click on the right arrow button.

Then click on F11 save.

We can observe that PI document is counted.

 

Post Physical inventory document.

Document posted.

We can observe PI doc is posted because book stock and system stock are same. So, PI Doc posted.

 

 

Conclusion:

The process for the Physical Inventory Application in SAP Fiori is provided.

entry.title: Process of creating Stock Transfer Order and Delivery using Purchase Requisition in SAP Fiori
entry.content:
Purchase Requisition:

  • A Purchase Requisition (PR) is an internal document requesting the procurement of materials or services.
  • It serves as a trigger for the purchasing department to create purchase orders.
  • PRs can be created manually or automatically based on MRP or consumption.

Stock Transfer Order (STO):

  • A Stock Transfer Order is used to move stock between plants or storage locations within an organization.
  • It ensures proper documentation and tracking of internal stock movements.
  • STOs can include delivery and billing steps, especially in intercompany scenarios.

Outbound Delivery:

  • An Outbound Delivery document controls the shipment of goods to a customer or another location.
  • It initiates warehouse activities such as picking, packing, and goods issue.
  • It is typically created from a sales order or stock transport order.

 

Process of creating Stock Transfer Order and Outbound Delivery using Purchase Requisition in SAP Fiori

Step1: Display Purchase requisition:

 

Step2:

In order to convert the Purchase requisitions to Purchase orders :Open the app- Create Purchase order Advanced

Select the Document Overview On:

Select the Variant :

 

Select the Purchase requisitions:

Choose Open only:

This selection will populate the Open Purchase requistions that as to be converted to purchase orders.

Input the Material, supplying plant

Select execute:

The above selection displays the Open Purchase requisitions.

Select the Purchase requisitions and Choose Adopt Icon.

The Purchase requisition details such as quantities, Delivery dates are copied into PO.

Change the Document type to UB: Stock transport order as highlighted.

The Supplying plant, material, quantities and delivery dates are copied from the Purchase requisition.

The Price fields will not be populated as this is an Intra stock transport order.

Scroll towards the column Issuing storage location and input the issuing storage location:

Select the Save option:

System generates the PO number:

 

 

Step3:

To ship the items from the warehouse we have to create an Outbound delivery document.

The Outbound delivery document acts as a reference document in the warehouse through which we can execute the Pick, pack and ship.

 On the dashboard.

Click on the app:

Input the Purchase order number and click on Execute:

Select the line item and choose background:

Select the line and choose the highlighted field to display the delivery number:

 The outbound delivery is displayed:

 

The Outbound delivery is created for the Stock Transfer Order.

 

Conclusion:

Process of creating Stock Transfer Order and Outbound Delivery using Purchase Requisition in SAP Fiori is provided.

entry.title: EWM Queue"Field Header: Receiving Office: Location No. is a required field for the action HDR: Save"
entry.content:
EWM Queue error: “Field Header: Receiving Office: Location No. is a required field for the action HDR: Save Node”

Field Header:

  • The Field Header typically refers to the top-level data in an SAP document that applies to the entire transaction (e.g., delivery, purchase order).
  • It includes general information such as document number, type, date, and partner details.
  • Header data is separated from item-level data to allow efficient processing and reporting.

 

Receiving Office:

  • The Receiving Office indicates the organizational unit or department responsible for receiving the goods or services.
  • It helps in identifying the internal recipient or cost center for incoming materials.
  • Often used in conjunction with purchasing documents to streamline goods receipt and accountability.

 

Location No (Location Number):

  • Location Number is a unique identifier for a physical or logical location within the warehouse or plant.
  • It is used for logistical tracking, planning, and inventory movements in modules like WM, EWM, and TM.
  • Location numbers help optimize storage, routing, and delivery processes across supply chain operations.

 

Replicating the EWM Queue Error

Step 1:
Create a purchase order using transaction code ME21N.


At the item level, maintain the inbound delivery type in the confirmation control field.


Once completed, the purchase order will be created.

 

Step 2:
Create an inbound delivery using transaction code VL31N.

Enter the supplier and purchase order details, provide the appropriate storage location, and save the document.


The inbound delivery will be created and should automatically be distributed to EWM.

 

Step 3:
The inbound delivery fails to distribute to EWM due to the following queue error:

EWM Queue Error:
Field Header: Receiving Office: Location No. is a required field for the action HDR: Save Node

This error occurs when the receiving office is not maintained in the associated Supply Chain Unit.

 

Solution Steps

Step 1:
Navigate to the configuration path to maintain the Supply Chain Unit using transaction code SPRO:
Logistics → SCWM Extended Warehouse Management → Extended Warehouse Management → Master Data → Define Supply Chain Unit.

 

Step 2:
On the “Supply Chain Unit: Initial Screen,” enter the relevant Supply Chain Unit and type, then click the “Change” button.


Go to the “Alternative” tab and create a business attribute with type RO (Goods Receipt Office). Save the changes.

Step 3:
Access transaction code SMQ2 and reprocess the failed queue.


The inbound delivery should now be distributed successfully to EWM.

 

Conclusion:

The EWM queue error related to the missing Receiving Office can be resolved by maintaining the appropriate business attribute in the Supply Chain Unit.
Once corrected, reprocessing the queue allows successful distribution of the inbound delivery to EWM.

entry.title: SAP EWM Performance analysis tools
entry.content:
SAP EWM Performance analysis tools 

In this blog I will focus on the available Standard Tools for SAP EWM Performance analysis

When we talk about performance is very important topic to consider different factor due the volume of transaction daily and activities performance in the Warehouse using PPF.

Tx: SPPFCADM

Process flow PPF framework:

 

    • Action Profile what is collect the actions. Actions has some kind of parameter, some settings what says how the action is processed. 
    • Schedule Condition decides that in the given process is should be triggered or not from business point of view.
    • Merge Logic does a grouping from technical point of view (e.g.: only one action allowed on a given object - it means even if business point of view a new action could be triggered, but the merge logic does not allow it, so only one action can be triggered and executed.
    • Automatic Schedule decides it should be automatically scheduled or not (usually it is automatically scheduled, if not it is edit so called Worklist and there manually can be executed).
    • Processing Time can be synchronous, asynchronous or manual.
    • Start Condition (not the execution yet) is very similar as the Schedule Condition. It is also based on business logic - do we needs to start the execution? Sometimes the logic behind these two it exactly the same, but we need it because these can be in different time, because of the processing time (synchronous - at the same time, asynchronous - can be executed different day these two, so in Start Condition we can check again that the business point of view is still valid, or not yet)
    • Processing Type means so called method type is processed.

 

As most of the process inside EWM is trigger using PPF Action is a heavy point to be review frequently for the PPF logs for performance optimization

  • Transaction /SCWM/DLVPPFLOG: Log of PPF actions of the PPF application /SCDL/DELIVERY (delivery).
  • Transaction /SCWM/WOHULOG: Log of the PPF print actions of the PPF application /SCWM/WME (HU, WO, PI, VAS).
  • Transaction /SCWM/ACTLOG: Many different log subobjects, such as the warehouse task processing log (for example). Here, the logs should be configured in such a way that the "No Info." setting is activated. Also, only important messages (error messages) are to be considered when setting the value for the parameter 'Log Active'
  • Transaction /SCWM/PSLOG: Packspec determination analysis should be activated only in test operation/test systems.
  • For cleaning up log entries the following reports can be used:
  • SBAL_DELETE_ORPHAN_MESSAGES
  • SBAL_STATISTICS

How to check database table sizing and health?

SE11 and SE16 transactions can be used. Check the planned table sizing in SE11 and the actual size in SE16 and compare them.
For the detailed steps please check the following page, and adjust the table name: 

Clear PPFTTRIGG with report

Purpose of the report: cleaning up the database tables of the PPF triggers to improve the performance.
Steps in general:

  1. Checking the size category in SE11
  2. Comparing it to the actual number of entries in the database table (SE16)
  3. Clean up the unnecessary entries.

Check the Size Category

SE11 PPFTTRIGG

 

Check the table size

SE16 PPFTTRIGG

Clear the table

SE38 

/SCWM/DELETE_PPF_TRIGGERS

Delete unnecessary PPF triggers

In EWM versions up to 9.4 + S/4HANA 1610 Embedded EWM

/SCDL/DELETE_PPF_TRIGGERS

Delete unnecessary PPF triggers

In EWM version 9.5 + S/4HANA versions 1709 and up

 

Fill as many field as you can with specific information.
If needed you can raise the Package Size to 10,000, and run e.g. 4 different session into 4 different time frames to avoid the program to run through the same PPF actions.

Notes

2780937    Performance Issue in program /SCDL/DELETE_PPF_TRIGGERS , /SCWM/DELETE_PPF_TRIGGERS 
2684482    Report /SCWM/DELETE_PPF_TRIGGERS correction 
2616601    /SCWM/DELETE_PPF_TRIGGERS report improvement 
2561323    Extended functionality for report /SCWM/DELETE_PPF_TRIGGERS
1975173    Delete unnecessary PPF triggers

 

Also consider the Transactions for analysis:

  • ST12 - Combined Performance & ABAP Trace, Single Transaction Analysis, eg. SQL queries
  • SE30 - Performance / ABAP, database, system OLD
  • ST05 - Performance - trace, OLD
  • STAD - Workload: Business Transaction Analysis, Performance, trace, e.g. http responses, CPU times etc. (Authorization Object S_TOOLS_EX)
  • ANST - Automated Note Search Tool, run against a transaction to see what notes are recommended.
  • ATC Administration - see below
  • SQLM - This tool can be activated for 1 or 2 weeks in a system and  tracks all SQL statements that are executed on the database level. Create a snapshot about this time period with Manage/Create Snapshots button, download it.
  • SWLT - see below
  • ST03 - Workload overview
  • ST06 - Operating system monitor (e.g. checking the memory size, user and system utilization)
  • SM50 - Work Processes
  • SM66 - Work Processes for All Application Server Instances
  • SARFC - Server Resources
  • SM51 - Application Server Instances
  • DB01 - DBA Cockpit (Database Administration) - System Configuration Display
  • RZ12 - RFC Server Group Maintenance
  • SM21 - Performance Assistant - System Log
  • /SDF/SMON - Snapshot Monitoring
  • DBACOCKPIT - Database Administration Cockpit (authorization object S_DBCON will be needed)
  • SLG0 - Application Log: Object Maintenance

Consulting notes:
755977 - ST12 "ABAP Trace for SAP EarlyWatch/GoingLive"
948066 - Performance Analysis: Transactions to use

Refer to :

Performance analysis tools (EWM) | SAP Help Portal

Early Watch Alert in EWM | SAP Help Portal

Hope that can help you.

Thank you and regards

Rogerio Lima.

entry.title: Embedded launch activities for SAP S/4HANA PCE for Extended Warehouse Management extra stack
entry.content:
Have you recently subscribed to SAP EWM extra stack and are gearing up for a project implementation? Starting off on the right foot is crucial to ensuring a smooth and successful SAP experience. That’s why SAP launched this Customer Onboarding Journey, specifically for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, Extended Warehouse Management, extra stack. This journey provides the foundational steps, resources, and support you need to drive your implementation with clarity and confidence. 

What’s Your Next Step? 

1. Embedded launch activities 

If you’ve signed your SAP EWM Extra-Stack contract after April 15th 2025, you’re entitled to the embedded launch activities. A no-cost onboarding framework based on 3 pillars: 

  • Onboarding Journey 
  • Guided Enablement
  • Adoption Touchpoint 

Your journey begins with an onboarding experience guided by an assigned Onboarding Advisor, ensuring you're set up for success from day one. 

      2. Explore the SAP EWM Onboarding Resource Center 

Your centralized hub for a smooth onboarding experience. Access open enablement resources, including:  

  • Step-by-step guidance on using SAP for Me 
  • System access instructions 
  • Clear expectations and preparation tips for your implementation project 

       3. Join the Onboarding Webcasts 

These quarterly live sessions are designed to guide you through the Onboarding Resource Center, provide key insights, answer your questions, and help you quickly get up to speed with SAP EWM.  

  • Can’t make it live? Don’t worry—on-demand recordings are available whenever you need them. 

  

Your Onboarding Journey: Designed for Success 

The SAP EWM onboarding journey is carefully structured to provide value from contract start to Go-Live and beyond. It consists of three core elements: 

  • Onboarding Sessions 
  • Self-Paced Learning (Guided Enablement) 
  • Continuous Quality Checks (CQC) 

 

Let’s break each phase down. 

 

  1. Onboarding Sessions (Live 1:1 Virtual Meetings) 

 Shortly after your contract begins, an SAP Onboarding Advisor will invite your team (and your partner, if applicable) to two live virtual sessions: 

  • Session 1: Welcome to SAP 
    • Introduction to your onboarding journey 
    • System provisioning and user setup 
    • Explanation of your solution entitlements 
  • Session 2: Implementation Preparation 
    • Best practices for project execution 
    • SAP Cloud ALM, Enterprise Support Overview and Business AI  

📌Target Audience: IT contact, business process owners, project leads, implementation partners 

  

  1. Guided Enablement (Self-Paced Learning Courses) 

 To empower your team further, SAP offers a 4-hour Cloud Onboarding for SAP EWM course via SAP Learning. This course covers:  

  • Get Started: S-User creation, system access, SAP for Me, SAP Trust Center 
  • Plan Your Implementation: Activate methodology, Cloud ALM, testing and integration 
  • Get Enabled: SAP Help Portal, Business AI, value maps 
  • Prepare to Go-Live: CQC planning, ALM monitoring, upgrade strategy 

 📌 Ideal for: Project teams including IT, admins, partners, and business users 

📎Access here: SAP Learning – Cloud Onboarding for EWM  

  

  1. Adoption Touchpoint (Continuous Quality Check for Private Cloud Go-Live) 

 The CQC for Private Cloud Go-Live is a two-session remote service evaluating your system’s readiness: 

  • Pre-Go-Live Analysis: 3–4 weeks before go-live 
  • Post-Go-Live Verification: 6 weeks after go-live 

 Each session results in a prioritized action plan to address system stability, performance, and optimization according to SAP Best Practices.  

📎More info: CQC Info Sheet (SAP) 

  

Ready to Begin? 

Don’t wait until challenges arise - start your onboarding journey today to build a strong foundation for your SAP EWM implementation. 

 

📩Have questions or need support? Contact your Account Executive, Onboarding Advisor or visit the SAP EWM Onboarding Resource Center.

entry.title: Process for Manual Completion of the Open Deliveries
entry.content:
Manual Completion of the open deliveries process when the EWM delivery is rejected and queue fails to process from EWM to S4HANA

Delivery:

  • A delivery document represents the movement of goods, either inbound (receipts) or outbound (shipments).
  • It triggers warehouse activities such as picking, packing, and goods issue/posting.
  • Deliveries are essential for linking sales/purchase orders to logistics execution processes.

EWM (Extended Warehouse Management):

  • SAP EWM manages complex warehouse operations with real-time visibility and control.
  • It supports advanced features like slotting, labor management, and automation integration.
  • EWM handles warehouse tasks based on delivery documents from S/4HANA.

S/4HANA:

  • S/4HANA is SAP's next-generation ERP suite built on the in-memory HANA database.
  • It offers a simplified data model, modern UX (Fiori), and real-time analytics.
  • Core business processes like Finance, Logistics, and Manufacturing are seamlessly integrated.

Queue:

  • Queues in SAP (especially in EWM integration) manage asynchronous data transfers between systems.
  • They help ensure reliable communication when messages cannot be processed immediately.
  • Errors in queues (e.g., stuck deliveries) must be monitored and resolved to ensure data consistency.

 

Step to perform the Manual Completion of the open deliveries process when the EWM delivery is rejected and queue fails to process from EWM to S4HANA

Step1: 

Create an outbound delivery using VL01N transaction code.

 

Step2:

Outbound delivery is distributed to EWM.

Then reject the delivery using the process code.

 

Step3:

Queue fails to process from EWM to S4HANA

 

Step4:

Since the status shows as “Not yet” started in S4 delivery.

Navigate to the tcode “VL_COMPLETE“ to manually complete the open delivery.

Provide the below details:

Delivery

Created On Date

And then execute.

Then select the delivery line and then process it by click on the flag icon.

A dialog box appears as “Adjust Delivery Status”. Then select the option “Yes”.

The goods movement status is changed from not started (A) to completed (C).

Delivery successfully processed is displayed.

 

Step5: 

The good movement status is changed to completed in the S4 delivery.

Conclusion:

Manual completion of the open deliveries process when the EWM delivery is rejected and the queue fails to process from EWM to S4HANA is provided.

entry.title: Creation of Production order and Release of production order using SAP Fiori Applications
entry.content:
Production Order:

  • A production order is a document that instructs the shop floor to manufacture a specific quantity of material.
  • It includes key details such as material components, routing steps, and scheduled dates.
  • The order integrates with inventory, costing, and capacity planning in SAP.

 

Production Order Release:

  • Releasing a production order authorizes the start of manufacturing activities.
  • It enables material staging, time confirmations, and goods movements.
  • Without release, the order cannot proceed to execution or posting of actuals.

 

SAP Fiori Applications:

  • SAP Fiori provides a modern, role-based UI for intuitive and mobile-friendly access to SAP functions.
  • Fiori apps streamline operations such as creating, monitoring, and releasing production orders.
  • Key apps include “Create Production Order” and “Manage Production Orders,” improving user efficiency and visibility.

 

Creation of Production Order

Step 1:
From the SAP Fiori dashboard, select the "Create Production Order" tile.

 

Step 2:
Enter the Material Number, Production Plant, and Order Type, then click Continue.

 

Step 3:
Specify the Order Quantity and Basic End Date, then press Enter.

Click on Schedule Order to perform scheduling.

The production order is now created.

 

Release of Production Order

Step 1:
From the Fiori dashboard, open the "Manage Production Orders" application.

 

Step 2:
Enter the MRP Controller and click on the Go button to display relevant orders.

 

Step 3:
Select the desired production orders and click Release.


The selected orders will be successfully released.

 

Conclusion

This guide outlines the process of creating and releasing a production order using SAP Fiori applications for efficient production planning and execution.

entry.title: Storage Bins Upload in SAP EWM using transaction code /N/SCWM/SBUP
entry.content:
Steps to perform Storage Bin Upload in SAP EWM using transaction code /N/SCWM/SBUP:

Step 1:
Navigate to the "Load Storage Bin" option from the SAP Easy Access screen, or directly enter the transaction code /SCWM/SBUP.

Step 2:
The Load Storage Bin screen will appear. Click on the folder icon to proceed with file selection.

Step 3:
Select the input file in CSV format, which must include the following fields:

  • Warehouse Number
  • Storage Bin
  • Storage Type
    Click on the Upload button to import the data.

Step 4:
If prompted with the "SAP GUI Security" dialog box, check the "Remember My Decision" option and click Allow to proceed.

 

Step 5:
The system will display a preview of the records from the input file.


Click the Create icon. A confirmation message will appear:
"1 storage bin created"

Step 6:
You can verify the created storage bin using transaction codes /n/SCWM/MON (Warehouse Monitor) or /n/SCWM/LS03 (Display Storage Bin).

Conclusion:

This guide outlines the steps to upload storage bins in SAP EWM using transaction code /SCWM/SBUP, allowing for efficient bin creation from a CSV input file.

entry.title: Solution for SAP Error message "Party Entitled to dispose is not allowed in warehouse number"
entry.content:
Party Entitled to Dispose:

  • The Party Entitled to Dispose refers to the organizational unit that owns the stock in SAP EWM.

  • It determines who has the legal right to make decisions about the goods (e.g., transfer, sell).

  • This is critical in third-party logistics or shared warehouse scenarios to segregate stock ownership.

 

PSA (Production Supply Area):

  • A production supply area is a logical area near a production line where materials are supplied for manufacturing.

  • It connects warehouse processes with production orders in SAP EWM and S/4HANA.

  • PSAs ensure the right materials are staged and available at the right location for production.

 

PSA Staging:

  • PSA staging is the process of transferring required components from the warehouse to the production supply area.

  • It is triggered by a production order and can be handled manually or automatically.

  • SAP EWM manages PSA staging through warehouse tasks and delivery-based staging methods.

 

Storage Locations:

  • A storage location in SAP defines a specific physical or logical area within a plant where materials are stored.

  • It helps organize inventory for easier tracking and management.

  • Storage locations are essential for stock segregation, valuation, and inventory management processes.

 

The error message "Party entitled to dispose is not allowed in warehouse number" displays when maintaining the PSA staging.

 

Why it’s required to maintain:

The new entry should be maintained for the production supply area staging cutover activity in production. This is required to ensure the following two:

  1. Determination of the storage bin for staging to the PSA
  2. Determination of the storage bin for the consumption of products from the PSA

 

Solution for the error message:

The following entries need to be maintained in the production system for "Mapping storage locations from the ERP system to EWM".

 

Once the required configuration is created, PSA staging can be maintained as shown in the below screenshot.

entry.title: EWM Queue Error “Field Item: Batch Number is a require field for the action HDR: PDO save Document"
entry.content:
In this blog, queues which are failed due to error message "Field Item: Batch Number is a require field for the action HDR: PDO save Document" will be resolved with step by step approach.

Issue Overview:

An Inbound Delivery is created without a batch number for a material which is maintained as batch-managed in material master.
Upon saving the delivery, its status changes to “B” (Distributed).As a result, an EWM inbound queue error occurs with the message:

“Field Item: Batch Number is a required field for the action HDR: PDO Save Document Header.”

Steps to replicate the Issue:

Step 1:
Check in.material master to confirm that the material is batch-managed.

 

Step2:

The Inbound delivery as displayed in the below screenshot is created without batch

 

Step3:

On Saving the delivery, header status - Dec Whse for the delivery is changed to “B” (Distributed).

 

The EWM Error queue error occurs with the message as “Field Item: Batch Number is a require field for the action HDR: PDO save Document Header”

 

 

Solution to resolve the EWM Queue:

Step1:

To resolve this , intial step is to save the queue with error using the transaction code SMQ2.

 

Step2:

From transaction code SE37, execute FM (Function Module) :  /SPE/DELV_RESET_DIST_STATUS

 

Once executed - this will reset the delivery’s distribution status from "B" (Distributed) to "A" (Relevant).

 

 

 

 

 Step3:

Delivery is now open and can be changes - hence a new batch can be created or assigned for the line items in the inbound delivery.

 

Step4:

Once completed - save S4 inbound delivery to  re-trigger the distribution to EWM, with updated batch information included, to process queues sucessfully.

 

Conclusion:

Provided  solution resolves EWM queue error “Field Item: Batch Number is a required field for the action HDR: PDO Save Document Header” by resetting the distribution status, maintaining batch data, and successfully re-distributing the delivery to EWM.

entry.title: Stock Upload in SAP EWM using the Transaction Code /N/SCWM/ISU
entry.content:
Steps to perform for Stock Upload in SAP EWM using the Transaction Code /N/SCWM/ISU

Step 1:
Navigate to “Stock Data Transfer” in the SAP Easy Access menu or directly enter the transaction code /N/SCWM/ISU.

 

 

Step 2:
The Stock Data Transfer screen will appear.
Enter Warehouse Number, and click on the folder icon to select input file.

 

 

Step 3:
Navigate to the upload file as displayed in the screenshot, and select on the Upload button to upload data.

Prompt with the "SAP GUI Security" dialog box will be displayed, check “Remember My Decision” and click “Allow” .

 

Step 4:
Uploaded data will be displayed in the highlighted section.

Click the Execute button to process the stock upload.

 

Step 5:
A Warehouse Task will be automatically created for the uploaded stock.

 

 

Step 6:
To verify the uploaded material and quantity, go to transaction /N/SCWM/MON (Warehouse Monitor).

 

Step 7:
In the background, movement type 561 is triggered to post the stock into the ERP system.
You can verify this posting in transaction MB51.

 

Conclusion:

Steps to perform Stock Upload in SAP EWM using the Transaction Code /N/SCWM/ISU is provided.

entry.title: SAP EWM Physical Inventory with /SCWM/PI_COUNTLIST
entry.content:
As an SAP EWM consultant, I often come across warehouses that still rely on paper-based inventory counts. Not every site uses RF devices or mobile solutions for physical inventory. For those environments, SAP provides a very handy transaction: /SCWM/PI_COUNTLIST.

In this blog, I’d like to share a quick insight into /SCWM/PI_COUNTLIST tcode. Whether you're printing paper-based count lists or just exploring physical inventory processes, this blog will help you get started.

 

The /SCWM/PI_COUNTLIST transaction takes the items from your physical inventory (PI) documents and formats them in a structured layout that warehouse staff can use to record counted quantities by hand. This is especially helpful in warehouses without RF devices.

As follows once a PI document has been created (/SCWM/PI_CREATE), you can use /SCWM/PI_COUNTLIST by entering PI document number.

Mark the "Storage Bin Empty" checkbox if the storage bin is physically empty, or select "PI Zero Count" if no stock is found for that specific material during the physical count.

Use the "Quantity in AUoM" field to enter the actual counted quantity in the alternative unit of measure as shown in the screenshot above.

Also by selecting the relevant item and clicking the "Display PI Doc Item" button, the system will navigate you directly to the /SCWM/PI_PROCESS screen, where you can view and enter the physical inventory details.

While /SCWM/PI_COUNTLIST is great for many physical inventory scenarios, it's important to understand that this transaction was designed primarily for simple stock structures such as products placed directly in storage bins, or basic cases like a product in a handling unit (HU), with the HU stored in a bin.

However, it does not support complex inventory structures, such as handling unit hierarchies and serial number managed products.

If you're working with any of these scenarios you should use /SCWM/PI_PROCESS or /SCWM/PI_COUNT instead. These transactions provide more flexibility and visibility for complex counting scenarios. (https://me.sap.com/notes/3265297/E)

 

Even in today’s digital warehouses, manual processes still exist and sometimes they’re necessary. /SCWM/PI_COUNTLIST helps bridge the gap between system data and manual operations. It gives warehouse workers a clear, organized way to count stock and ensures that physical inventory processes stay reliable, even without mobile tools.

This was a small but useful function that I believe doesn’t get enough attention. If your site handles manual counting make sure you check out /SCWM/PI_COUNTLIST. It’s simple to use, easy to adjust, and can make physical inventory runs much smoother.

 

Thanks for reading!

Note;

If you performed your physical inventory count using Excel and want to upload the results into the system all at once, you can use the PI_UPLOAD process and for that you can check the following blog post;

https://community.sap.com/t5/supply-chain-management-blog-posts-by-members/ewm-physical-inventory-pi-upload-transaction/ba-p/13430503

 

References

Processing of Physical Inventory Documents | SAP Help Portal

Compare Physical Inventory IM - WM - EWM - SAP Community

About the limitations;

https://me.sap.com/notes/3265297/E

https://me.sap.com/notes/3375080/E

https://me.sap.com/notes/3401785/E

entry.title: Complete your Advanced Shipping & Receiving (ASR) process with a PGI event
entry.content:
A common requirement in TM-EWM projects is the need to update the execution status or report an event on freight orders after the PGI. When configuring the Advanced Shipping & Receiving process, it is possible to specify the event that should be reported after the goods movement in the outbound processes.

This makes it possible to make your process more agile and cohesive, and to provide feedback to your freight order with all the necessary information, aiming to have a single point of reference for the process progress.

For this purpose, SAP provides the TM Save Strategy called PGI_REP_EV shown in the print below, which must be configured in the freight orders relevant to the ASR process:

After the entire process is executed in the ASR, our freight order will have these events, where the next step is the execution of the PGI and then the departure from door, which are executed in the Load or Unload Freight Orders app. Without the above configuration, only during the "departure from door" step is an event reported, which in this case is "Departure From Door".

This way we go to the "Load or unload Freight Orders" App and perform the PGI:

And this way, the "Checkout" event is reported. Additionally, according to the ASR process itself, the "Departure From Door" event is automatically reported. This occurs through the /scmtms/cl_tor_set_dep_wh_door-set_wh_door_departed class/method, which performs a series of additional checks to report this additional event along with the "Checkout" event. This way, we complete the entire process with just the PGI.

Therefore, it will not be necessary to run this departure process on the monitor:

An important point is that it's possible to configure the event that will be reported for this strategy. As mentioned above, the reported event was "Checkout". This event was determined through a process controller parameter linked to the method and the standard strategy. However, the class is prepared to be configured with a custom strategy (ZPGI_REP_E) and a custom parameter (ZEVENT_CODE), so you can determine which event will be reported via configuration:

To do this:

  • Create your own strategy according to the name described in the code and include the same method as the standard strategy
  • Create the parameter also with the custom name described
  • And then assign the event code to the parameter and strategy in this last menu of the process controller configuration:

entry.title: The SAP Extended Warehouse Management FAQ Series: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Integration
entry.content:
Many customers running standardized processes for their Finance, Controlling and Order Management processes in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud are searching for options to integrate advanced warehouse management functionalities to cover their logistics process requirements and help them to grow their business.

With SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 a new scope item enabling integration of SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud with EWM for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud will be available, to combine standardized cloud ERP processes to be integrated with advanced warehouse management capabilities.

With this blog post are discussing questions and interesting information around the integration of SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and EWM for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud.

Which release is required to setup the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and EWM for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud integration?

With SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 a new scope item will be shipped - SAP EWM for SAP S/4HANA Integration (7L1). This includes the new communication scenario Logistics - S/4HANA Extended Warehouse Management Integration (SAP_COM_0A58) that enables the integration of transactional data to a decentral EWM for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud or OnPremise.

Minimum required SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud release is 2023, FPS0 if batch master data distribution is not required. Otherwise, SAP S/4HANA Private Cloude release 2023, FPS3, introducing the batch master data distribution via DRF is the required minimum release.

Which functional scope is supported in the integration?

The following processes are supported in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud integration to a decentral EWM for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud:

Process

see also Scope Item

Inbound processing from supplier

2VJ - SAP EWM Integration - Inbound Processing from Supplier

Outbound processing to customer

2VK - SAP EWM Integration - Outbound Processing to Customer

Delivery based production integration: Production supply and goods receipt

2VM - SAP EWM Integration - Delivery-Based Production Integration

Customer returns

2VO - SAP EWM Integration - Customer Returns 

Batch management - Creating batches in: 

•       SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition ERP system

•       SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition EWM system

2VN - SAP EWM Integration - Batch Management

Stock transport orders

2VL - SAP EWM Integration - Stock Transport Orders 

What do I have to know about the technical setup of the integration?

To setup the integration there are cut-over, customizing and integration settings required to establish the integration from SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud to SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud via SAP Cloud Connector and vice versa via WebSocket. Please find detailed information about the integration via official Set-Up Instruction - Setting Up SAP EWM for SAP S/4HANA Integration (7L1).

Which deployment scenarios are supported?

We are supporting the integration of a single SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud tenant (with or without Cloud WM) to a single EWM for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud instance. Additionally, a further SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud instance can be integration to the same EWM for SAP S/4HANA.

Please note that the SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud instance can only be used as a decentral EWM logistics system as the integration of multiple SAP S/4HANA or SAP ECC systems to EWM on SAP S/4HANA embedded not supported (see also SAP Note 3376453 - SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS00, FPS01, FPS02 and FPS03: Release information and restrictions for EWM in SAP S/4HANA).

Are there any restriction to be considered implementing this integration to EWM for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud?

There are functional restrictions for EWM on SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud integrating with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud to be considered. These can be distinguished by supported processes and integration capabilities managed via Control Parameters for ERP Version Control.

Please find a list of most important processes and functions not supported in the integration in the table below:

Process/Functions

Details

Handling Unit Management in EWM in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition

Handling Units can only be managed within SAP EWM. They are not integrated into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition. Handling Units created in EWM for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud are not transferred to deliveries in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition.

Serial Numbers on warehouse level

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition offers Serial Numbers on the document level (A), the warehouse level (B) and the stock level (C). SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition only offers Serial Numbers on the (A) document and (C) stock levels.​ Serial Number on document and stock level supported for integration scenario only.

Transport Integration – Shipment (LE-TRA) – Transportation Unit

Integration of Transportation Units via SHPMNT05-Idoc to LE-TRA component (Shipments) is not supported in SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud integration.

Integration with SAP Transportation Management (TM)

The integration with Transportation Management (e.g. Via Transportation Units or Advanced Shipping and Receiving) is not supported.

Find a complete list of restrictions and learn more about the new integration between SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and EWM for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud via SAP Note 3629180 - Supported Processes for EWM Integration with SAP_COM_0A58 - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and Higher.

Learn more about this integration via SAP Help - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 - Feature Scope Description.
